prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity Although CO(1-0) peak temperature was measured to be < 1K with Mopra, the expected antenna temperature would be ~10K when we can spatially resolve molecular clouds. The typical line-width is ~5km/s. Then we set the sensitivity at 0.5K with a velocity resolution of 0.4km/s. We set the other 3 available basebands to continuum observations for the possible detection of the thermal/synchrotron emission from the source.
Angular resolution We need an spatial resolution to resolve the molecular cloud. We then choose a spatial resolution of 3 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.7pc.

Sensitivity Although CO(1-0) peak temperature was measured to be < 1K with Mopra, the expected antenna temperature in 13CO would be ~5K when we can spatially resolve molecular clouds. For high density trasers of C18O and CS, the antenna temperature can be < 1K. The typical line-width is ~5km/s. Then we set the sensitivity at 0.15K with a velocity resolution of 0.5km/s.
Angular resolution We need spatial resolutions to resolve the molecular cloud. We then choose a spatial resolution of 3 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.7pc.

Sensitivity Although CO(1-0) peak temperature was measured to be < 1K with Mopra, the expected antenna temperature in 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) would be ~5-10K when we can spatially resolve molecular clouds. For a high density traser of C18O, the antenna temperature can be < 1K. The typical line-width is ~5km/s. Then we set the sensitivity at 0.15K with a velocity resolution of 0.5km/s. We also set the other baseband to H(30)alpha to investigate the ionization by the YSOs.
Angular resolution We need spatial resolutions to resolve the molecular cloud. We then choose a spatial resolution of 3 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.7pc. Mosaic observations with ACA will be used to recover the extended emission (>~20 arcsec for 12CO and 13CO) to acculately derive J=2-1/1-0 ratios.

Sensitivity The estimation of the CI intensity is somewhat uncertain because we don't know the abundance in the observed region. Judjing from the galactic case, the intensity is 5-10K, and then we we set the sensitivity at 0.3K with a velocity resolution of 0.4km/s.
Angular resolution We need spatial resolutions to resolve the molecular cloud. We then choose a spatial resolution of 1.5 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.35pc. This resolution is the lowest which can be selected. Areas to be covered The primary beam and the main array largest recoverable scale become very small at this frequency compared with Band 3 and Band 6 observations. In order to compare the CI distribution with the Band 3 and Band 6 observations, we request Mosaic observations with ACA.

Sensitivity The estimation of the CI intensity is somewhat uncertain because we don't know the abundance in the observed region. Judjing from the galactic case, the intensity is 5-10K, and then we we set the sensitivity at 0.3K with a velocity resolution of 0.4km/s.
Angular resolution We need spatial resolutions to resolve the molecular cloud. We then choose a spatial resolution of 1.5 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.35pc. This resolution is the lowest which can be selected. Areas to be covered The primary beam and the main array largest recoverable scale become very small at this frequency compared with Band 3 and Band 6 observations. In order to compare the CI distribution with the Band 3 and Band 6 observations, we request Mosaic observations with ACA.

Sensitivity The estimation of the CI intensity is somewhat uncertain because we don't know the abundance in the observed region. Judjing from the galactic case, the intensity is 5-10K, and then we we set the sensitivity at 0.3K with a velocity resolution of 0.4km/s.
Angular resolution We need spatial resolutions to resolve the molecular cloud. We then choose a spatial resolution of 1.5 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.35pc. This resolution is the lowest which can be selected. Areas to be covered The primary beam and the main array largest recoverable scale become very small at this frequency compared with Band 3 and Band 6 observations. In order to compare the CI distribution with the Band 3 and Band 6 observations, we request Mosaic observations with ACA.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High-mass stars usually form in giant molecular clouds (GMCs) as part of a young stellar cluster, but some isolated O/B stars are observed. What are the initial conditions that lead to the formation of these objects? The aim of the proposed observations is to measure the distribution and basic physical properties of the neutral gas associated with 12 isolated intermediate- and high-mass young stellar objects (YSOs) in the Large Magellanic Cloud. We have identified and confirmed the YSOs using Spitzer IRAC photometry and IRS spectroscopy, and single-dish CO observations by our team put upper limits between a few thousand and 10,000 solar masses on their associated reservoir of molecular gas. Here we propose observations of the 1-0 and 2-1 transitions of the main CO isotopes in order to measure the density, temperature and velocity structure of the CO clouds associated with the YSOs and, for a subset of sources, CI observations to investigate the distribution of the neutral gas components without CO emission. The observations will provide the basic empirical measurements that are required to develop a theory for isolated high mass star-formation.
